summary: herpes simplex infection (HSV-1) has been shown to be a risk factor in Alzheimer's disease. acting in synergy with possession of the APOE4 allele HSV-1 infection in mice or neuroblastoma cells increases beta-amyloid deposition and phosphorylation of the microtubule protein tau. viral infection also results in hippocampal and entorhinal cortex neuronal degeneration, brain shrinkage, and memory loss, all as found in antigenicity was predicted using the BepiPred server [9] at http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/BepiPred/ and T cell epitopes predicted using the Immune epitope database resource at http://tools.immuneepitope.org/main/html/tcell_tools.html [10]. the results of the HSV-1 BLASTS, sized according to the number of viral hits per protein, are shown in Table 2. all of the genes encoding for these proteins with the exception of those with the strikethrough have been implicated in Alzheimer's disease in genetic association studies. BLAST returns the human proteins with the greatest homology to viral proteins. the unfiltered BLAST showed that herpes simplex viral proteins are highly homologous to a series of family members of diverse protein kinases. the homology is such as to suggest that such phosphorylation may be accomplished by the viral proteins themselves. simplex virus as APOE4, clusterin, complement receptor 1, and PICALM are homologous to proteins from a diverse array of phages and viruses. many proteins will be homologous to proteins from specific subsets of viruses. several herpes species other than HSV-1 (HSV-2, 3, 6, 6B, and 8) fall into this category. the protein sequences highlighted in grey in Table 3 contain strings of herpes simplex proteins that have been shown to bind to several interactome partners of tau. these include APOE4, complement receptor 1, clusterin, insulin degrading enzyme, the APP homologue, APLP2, the collagen amyloid plaque component CLAC, synuclein, and the foetal Alzheimer antigen, ALZ50. vatches within Beta-Amyloid and the Microtubule Protein tau Vatches are short contiguous amino acid stretches that are identical in viral and human proteins. there are several million within the human proteome, derived from evolutionary descent and from the insertion of multiple viruses into the human genome over millions of years. reinsertions appear to be responsible for the creation of gene families. the repetitive patterns in the pictogram reflect homology with a number of different lipoprotein receptors located on different chromosomes. some of the vatches within beta-amyloid and tau correspond to highly antigenic regions of APP or tau, and therefore also of the HSV-1 proteins.
